        "text": "A lot of times people will just use straight eggs for this and that's okay, but the yolk is a lot of fat and the white is a lot of liquid."

Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Boil water in a large pot, add salt, and cook the spaghetti until it is al dente. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Meat\n\t- Definition: Chop the guanciale or bacon into small pieces and cook it in a pan over medium heat until it is crispy. Mix until smooth. Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta directly to the pan with the cooked meat. Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs. Add more pasta water if needed to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Cook Meat, Mix Sauce\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Serve Dish\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, adding extra grated cheese and black pepper on top as desired.     "role": "user",
    "content": "## Video 2:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for Pasta Carbonara, including thick-cut bacon or pancetta, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, eggs, fresh ground black pepper, and spaghetti. Ensure you have a cheese grater and a pepper grinder.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Cook Bacon\n\t- Definition: Slice the bacon into thick pieces and cook it in a pan over medium heat with a little olive oil until the fat is rendered and the bacon is crispy. Reserve some bacon for garnish and keep about two tablespoons of bacon fat in the pan.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Boil Pasta\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil, add a tablespoon of kosher salt, and cook the spaghetti until it is slightly al dente. Reserve some pasta water for later use.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Mix Cheese and Eggs\n\t- Definition: Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely. In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks, then gradually mix in the grated cheeses and a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Combine Pasta and Sauce\n\t- Definition: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with bacon fat (off the heat). Add the cheese and egg mixture to the pasta, stirring quickly to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Bacon, Boil Pasta, Mix Cheese and Eggs\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Serve Dish\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated Parmigiano Reggiano and the reserved crispy bacon pieces for garnish.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Pasta and Sauce\n"

  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Video 3:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for Pasta Carbonara: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta (such as spaghetti), black pepper, and optionally garlic. Ensure the guanciale is not too lean and the cheese is crumbly and salty.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Boil water with a small amount of salt. Twist the pasta and add it to the boiling water to prevent sticking. Cook the pasta for about 8 minutes until al dente.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Remove the skin from the guanciale and slice it into 1 cm thick pieces. Roughly chop these slices into 0.5 cm chunks. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and gradually heat it to medium-high to render the fat. Optionally, add cracked garlic to the pan to infuse flavor.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Crack Pepper\n\t- Definition: Use a pestle and mortar to crack black peppercorns. Sift to separate the milder outer skin from the hotter inner part, which will be used for the carbonara.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Mix Eggs and Cheese\n\t- Definition: Crack the eggs into a bowl and add about 20 grams of pecorino romano cheese. Whisk the mixture until well combined. This will form the base of the sauce.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Once the guanciale is golden and the fat is rendered, remove the garlic and turn off the heat. Drag the cooked pasta directly into the pan with the guanciale, adding some pasta water to stop frying and create an emulsion with the fat. Gradually add the egg and cheese mixture while tossing the pasta to create a creamy sauce. Adjust with more pasta water if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Eggs and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Finish Dish\n\t- Definition: Add the cracked black pepper to the pasta and toss to combine. Serve the pasta carbonara with a finishing sprinkle of pecorino romano cheese and additional black pepper if desired.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients, Crack Pepper\n"
  },

    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Video 4:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter of water. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add spaghettoni or another type of pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook for about 10 minutes until al dente. Do not add oil to the water.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale or pancetta into chunks. Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat and becomes crispy. Optionally, remove excess fat using a paper towel.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg Sauce\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks. Add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant black pepper. Mix well to form a creamy sauce. Do not add cream or salt.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with the guanciale. Allow it to cool slightly, then add the egg sauce. Stir quickly to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg Sauce\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Finish Dish\n\t- Definition: Serve the pasta carbonara with additional grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and a touch of black pepper for decoration and extra flavor.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Video 5:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon if substituting) into sizable chunks. This is the cured pork jowl that will be used in the Carbonara. If using bacon, ensure it's thick-cut.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Make Egg Mixture\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine three large eggs and one egg yolk. Finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese, using a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano if desired. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until homogenous.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium. Cook slowly to render out the fat until the guanciale is fully cooked but not too crispy. If using bacon, strain off excess fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Guanciale\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Boil Pasta\n\t- Definition: Boil pasta in water that is as salty as the sea. Stir to prevent sticking. Test for doneness by tasting a strand. Use spaghetti or bucatini as preferred.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Once the pasta is cooked, transfer it directly into the pan with the cooked guanciale. Toss to coat the pasta in the rendered fat. Quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce. Add pasta water if needed to adjust consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Guanciale, Boil Pasta, Make Egg Mixture\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Season and Serve\n\t- Definition: Taste the pasta for seasoning and add salt if necessary. Optionally, add more grated cheese to thicken the sauce if needed. Plate the pasta, twirling it for presentation, and top with remaining guanciale and sauce.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Video 6:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Toast Peppercorns\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan over medium-low heat until they become fragrant and start to pop. This enhances their flavor, giving a nutty and deep black pepper taste.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Grind Peppercorns\n\t- Definition: After toasting, let the peppercorns cool and then crush them using a pan or a pepper grinder to achieve a coarse texture. This step releases the oils and enhances the flavor.\n\t- Dependencies: Toast Peppercorns\n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Grate Cheeses\n\t- Definition: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheeses using a microplane to achieve a fine texture. This ensures the cheese melts smoothly into the sauce, providing a nutty and sharp flavor profile.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Eggs\n\t- Definition: Bring eggs to room temperature and separate three whole eggs and two additional yolks. This ensures the eggs mix well with the hot pasta without scrambling.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Mix Eggs and Cheese\n\t- Definition: Combine the grated cheeses with the eggs to form a smooth, homogenous mixture. Add some of the ground peppercorns to this mixture for flavor.\n\t- Dependencies: Grind Peppercorns, Grate Cheeses, Prepare Eggs\n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Cut Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale into thick matchstick-sized pieces. This ensures visible chunks in the dish, contributing to the texture and flavor.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Cook Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cook the guanciale in a pan with a little olive oil until it is light golden brown but not crispy. This renders the fat, which is essential for the sauce.\n\t- Dependencies: Cut Guanciale\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Boil spaghetti in salted water until al dente. The pasta should have a slight bite to it and not be overcooked.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 9**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Mix the cooked pasta with the egg and cheese mixture, adding the cooked guanciale and its fat. Stir vigorously to emulsify the sauce, ensuring it is creamy and coats the pasta well.\n\t- Dependencies: Mix Eggs and Cheese, Cook Guanciale, Cook Pasta\n- **Subgoal 10**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the pasta, topping it with additional guanciale, ground pepper, and grated cheese. Serve immediately while hot to enjoy the creamy texture and flavors.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"
  }
]

    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Subgoals:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti), eggs (using yolks and optionally whole eggs), Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese (optional), black pepper, and guanciale or pancetta/bacon as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water, Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon) into chunks. Place in a cold pan and gradually heat to render the fat until the guanciale is cooked and slightly crispy. Optionally, add garlic for flavor and remove excess fat if necessary.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Toast and Grind Pepper\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan until fragrant. Let them cool, then crush them to a coarse texture using a grinder or mortar and pestle.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine eggs (yolks and optionally whole eggs) with grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until smooth. Optionally, add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients, Toast and Grind Pepper\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with the guanciale and its rendered fat. Off the heat, quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated cheese, ground black pepper, and reserved crispy guanciale pieces. Serve immediately while hot.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"

Given the contents of the how-to video and subgoals, segment the video according to subgoals. If some subtitles do not belong to any subgoal, define custom subgoals."

  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Subgoals:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti), eggs (using yolks and optionally whole eggs), Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese (optional), black pepper, and guanciale or pancetta/bacon as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water, Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon) into chunks. Place in a cold pan and gradually heat to render the fat until the guanciale is cooked and slightly crispy. Optionally, add garlic for flavor and remove excess fat if necessary.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Toast and Grind Pepper\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan until fragrant. Let them cool, then crush them to a coarse texture using a grinder or mortar and pestle.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine eggs (yolks and optionally whole eggs) with grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until smooth. Optionally, add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients, Toast and Grind Pepper\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with the guanciale and its rendered fat. Off the heat, quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated cheese, ground black pepper, and reserved crispy guanciale pieces. Serve immediately while hot.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"

        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make traditional Pasta Carbonara correctly, using accessible ingredients like bacon instead of guanciale, and emphasizing the simplicity of the dish without unnecessary additions like cream.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.`; `It's so simple!`; `You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing the bacon by rendering its fat, cooking the pasta, and creating a cheese and egg mixture. The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God.       {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged. I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano. That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff. So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding. I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description. Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up. So here's all our beautiful cheese. Okay, now time for the eggs. A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks. I like to do a mixture of both. So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks. The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks. Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture. And you'll see all that, and it looked like so much cheese, right? But as this breaks down, it won't look like that anymore. Add that all in. And so now we have a consistency like this. Now, this is a very important time for our good friend, Sergeant Gilbert. I'm gonna put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture. If you didn't know already, Gilbert is just fresh ground black pepper. He's a sentient being, a pepper grinder, who became selfaware in 2020. You know, and this is preference. Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in."

    "role": "user",
    "content": [
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Context:\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make traditional Pasta Carbonara correctly, using accessible ingredients like bacon instead of guanciale, and emphasizing the simplicity of the dish without unnecessary additions like cream.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.`; `It's so simple!`; `You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing the bacon by rendering its fat, cooking the pasta, and creating a cheese and egg mixture. The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God. Looks so good.`; `And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.`; `Just get it off the tongs like so. Oh, man.`; `And of course, some of your crispy bacon. Just for an added crunch.`\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients mixture\n\t- ** Materials**: Bacon, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, eggs, black pepper, cheese grater or box grater.\n\t- ** Instructions**: 1. Slice bacon into thick pieces. 2. Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely. 3. Whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. 4. Mix grated cheese into the egg mixture. 5. Add ground black pepper to taste and whisk.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using a mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness without being overwhelming. Mixing two types of cheese adds depth of flavor.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use a cheese grater or box grater for fine cheese texture. Adjust pepper to personal taste.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Prepared mixture of sliced bacon, grated cheese, and whisked eggs with pepper, ready for cooking.\n"
      }
    ]

Use tongs to transfer the spaghetti to a baking pan.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Cooking the pasta slightly al dente allows it to finish cooking in the sauce, absorbing flavors without becoming mushy.\n\t- ** Tips**: Leave the pasta water in the pot as it will be used later.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Spaghetti is cooked slightly al dente and ready to be combined with other ingredients.\n"

Turn off the heat and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Rendering the fat slowly ensures the bacon becomes crispy without burning, and the fat is used to flavor the pasta.\n\t- ** Tips**: Do not add olive oil to the pasta; it's a myth that it helps.     "content": "You are a helpful assistant specializing in analyzing and segmenting how-to videos according to task graph for task `How to make Pasta Carbonara?`.   },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Subgoals:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti), eggs (using yolks and optionally whole eggs), Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese (optional), black pepper, and guanciale or pancetta/bacon as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water, Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon) into chunks. Place in a cold pan and gradually heat to render the fat until the guanciale is cooked and slightly crispy. Optionally, add garlic for flavor and remove excess fat if necessary.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Toast and Grind Pepper\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan until fragrant. Let them cool, then crush them to a coarse texture using a grinder or mortar and pestle.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine eggs (yolks and optionally whole eggs) with grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until smooth. Optionally, add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients, Toast and Grind Pepper\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with the guanciale and its rendered fat. Off the heat, quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated cheese, ground black pepper, and reserved crispy guanciale pieces. Serve immediately while hot.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"
  },

The dish is finished by combining the pasta with eggs and pecorino cheese, ensuring the right texture and flavor.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`So first up guys, grab the pasta by two hands.         "type": "text",
        "text": "Hi guys, we're gonna make spaghetti carbonara, a classic Italian dish. Pasta, cheese, bacon. What's not to love, right? But it's really controversial. I want to give you what I think is the most authentic recipe. So first up guys, you only need five ingredients. Guanciale. This is the cured cheek of pork. And as you can see, it's all about the fat. It's salted, it's got pepper, it's dried and it's aged. Of course, it's similar to smoked bacon and you can get some pretty good results actually. But you can see this is quite lean. So try and get them to not cut off the fat because you need it. Or there's pancetta. Then, most people use parmesan. But actually, the more classic is pecorino romano. Sheep's cheese. It's crumbly, it's salty, freerange organic egg. Pasta, black pepper and then optional, garlic."

      {
        "type": "text",

    "content": "You are a helpful assistant specializing in analyzing and segmenting how-to videos according to task graph for task `How to make Pasta Carbonara?`. Given the contents of the how-to video and subgoals, segment the video according to subgoals. If some subtitles do not belong to any subgoal, define custom subgoals."
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Subgoals:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti), eggs (using yolks and optionally whole eggs), Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese (optional), black pepper, and guanciale or pancetta/bacon as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water, Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon) into chunks. Place in a cold pan and gradually heat to render the fat until the guanciale is cooked and slightly crispy. Optionally, add garlic for flavor and remove excess fat if necessary.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Toast and Grind Pepper\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan until fragrant. Let them cool, then crush them to a coarse texture using a grinder or mortar and pestle.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine eggs (yolks and optionally whole eggs) with grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until smooth. Optionally, add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients, Toast and Grind Pepper\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with the guanciale and its rendered fat. Off the heat, quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated cheese, ground black pepper, and reserved crispy guanciale pieces. Serve immediately while hot.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"

    "role": "system",
    "content": "You are a helpful assistant specializing in analyzing and segmenting how-to videos according to task graph for task `How to make Pasta Carbonara?`. Given the contents of the how-to video and subgoals, segment the video according to subgoals. If some subtitles do not belong to any subgoal, define custom subgoals."
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Subgoals:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti), eggs (using yolks and optionally whole eggs), Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese (optional), black pepper, and guanciale or pancetta/bacon as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water, Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon) into chunks. Place in a cold pan and gradually heat to render the fat until the guanciale is cooked and slightly crispy. Optionally, add garlic for flavor and remove excess fat if necessary.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Toast and Grind Pepper\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan until fragrant. Let them cool, then crush them to a coarse texture using a grinder or mortar and pestle.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine eggs (yolks and optionally whole eggs) with grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until smooth. Optionally, add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients, Toast and Grind Pepper\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with the guanciale and its rendered fat. Off the heat, quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated cheese, ground black pepper, and reserved crispy guanciale pieces. Serve immediately while hot.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"
  },

        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Let's get down to basics."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "I've got maybe a half pound here that I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks, and then set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk for a little added richness."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese."

        "type": "text",

        "text": "We're then going to beat this whole affair together with a fork until homogenous."

      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We're not adding any salt yet because guanciale can vary in saltiness, and we don't want to oversalt our dish."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Beat that together until well incorporated, and then it's time to head over to the stovetop, where we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan."

      {
        "type": "text",

        "type": "text",

      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And you wanna work quickly here, because the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta."

      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So waste no time getting the egg and cheese mixture in there, and then agitate rigorously."

        "type": "text",
        "text": "But at this point, I'm gonna ask all Italians to leave the room, because it's time to make carbonara."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "This starts very much the same way, with Parmesan and Romano cheese grated into a bowl, along with three eggs and one egg yolk, beaten together with a few healthy twists of freshly ground black pepper."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now, when most Americans make carbonara, they reach for the bacon."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If you can't find guanciale or pancetta and you gotta use bacon, just go for the thickcut stuff."

      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "You'll also notice that I'm using a nonstick pan."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "That's because, in stainless, bacon can leave a lot of fond on the bottom of the pot, which, for once, we don't want, as it might make our final pasta look kinda dirty."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Once the bacon is fully cooked and the fat rendered out, we are going to strain it, because this version of carbonara is going to have a much lighter sauce."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We're just gonna strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat, which we're gonna leave in the pan, and then we're gonna return it over mediumlow heat to add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic."

        "type": "text",
        "text": "This is considered sacrilege in the world of carbonara, but I think it tastes really, really good, and so will you."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "We're just sauting for one minute until fragrant, before killing the heat."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Next up, I see far too many people just dump pasta out of the box in the water, which inevitably leads to disaster."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Give this a shot, where you dump the pasta in the palm of your hand, and then pull it out, using your hand like a real gentleman."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And as you can see, this time I'm going with bucatini."
      },

        "type": "text",
        "text": "Next up, just like last time, we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water, which is gonna help make a cohesive sauce."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Then we are adding the egg and cheese mixture to the party, and if you find yourself in a pickle like this, where your pan is too small to toss the pasta, no biggie, just dump it back into the emptied pasta pot."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Just make sure that you keep it moving, because there's a lot of residual heat in here, and we don't want to end up with pasta and scrambled eggs."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "So just wildly agitate that around, and then it's time to taste for seasoning."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Add salt and pepper as necessary, and assess your sauce's thickness."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "If it's not quite thick enough, you can rescue it with a little bit of finely grated parmesan."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Just add maybe another quarter ounce or so, and mix rigorously."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And now it's time to plate up, and one thing you'll notice about this carbonara, is that the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It also stays creamier longer, and won't congeal as quickly as carbonara."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And the bucatini, while a little bit difficult to get on one's fork, is dense and chewy and lovely."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",

      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Contents:\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch. I've got maybe a half pound here that I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks, and then set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry. Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk for a little added richness. And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese. Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano. If you want it a little less sharp and a little more nutty, I'm going for a 5050 ratio, into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs. We're then going to beat this whole affair together with a fork until homogenous. The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper."
      }
    ]
  }

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"
      }
    ]

This is gonna cook the guanciale more slowly, and allow more of its fat to render out, which, in traditional Carbonara, is a good thing.         "type": "text",
        "text": "Once all the pasta has been added, we're going to toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly covered in all that guanciale fat. And you wanna work quickly here, because the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta. So waste no time getting the egg and cheese mixture in there, and then agitate rigorously. This is going to help emulsify the sauce and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling. If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like, you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a quarter cup. But ideally, it should look just like this. Now we're gonna taste for seasoning. Mine needs a little bit of salt. Then you can optionally toss the pasta. This is gonna help aerate it a little bit, get that sauce super creamy."
      }

Quickly add egg and cheese mixture. Agitate to emulsify. Add pasta water if needed. Taste and adjust seasoning. Optionally toss to aerate.\n\t- ** Rationale**: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, making it smooth and creamy. Agitating helps emulsify the sauce and prevents curdling.\n\t- ** Tips**: Work quickly to prevent the eggs from curdling.       {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And then, finally, it's time to plate up. I like to use a carving fork to twirl the pasta into a giant cylinder, like this one, for presentation on a long, narrow plate. We are then, of course, going to want to top this hedonistic helix with the remaining guanciale from the bottom of the pan, along with any remnants of that creamy sauce. And there you have it, folks. I'm gonna say it one last time. Carbonara. In its purest, most authentic and traditional form. Unless, of course, I got something wrong, in which case I'm in trouble. But at this point, I'm gonna ask all Italians to leave the room, because it's time to make carbonara."

  {
    "role": "system",
    "content": "You are a helpful assistant specializing in analyzing and segmenting how-to videos according to task graph for task `How to make Pasta Carbonara?`. Given the contents of the how-to video and subgoals, segment the video according to subgoals. If some subtitles do not belong to any subgoal, define custom subgoals."
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": "## Subgoals:\n- **Subgoal 1**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti), eggs (using yolks and optionally whole eggs), Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese (optional), black pepper, and guanciale or pancetta/bacon as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 2**:\n\t- Title: Boil Water\n\t- Definition: Bring a pot of water to a boil and add salt. Ensure the water is boiling before adding pasta.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 3**:\n\t- Title: Cook Pasta\n\t- Definition: Add pasta to the boiling salted water. Stir occasionally and cook until al dente. Reserve some pasta water before draining.\n\t- Dependencies: Boil Water, Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 4**:\n\t- Title: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- Definition: Cut guanciale (or pancetta/bacon) into chunks. Place in a cold pan and gradually heat to render the fat until the guanciale is cooked and slightly crispy. Optionally, add garlic for flavor and remove excess fat if necessary.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients\n- **Subgoal 5**:\n\t- Title: Toast and Grind Pepper\n\t- Definition: Toast whole black peppercorns in a pan until fragrant. Let them cool, then crush them to a coarse texture using a grinder or mortar and pestle.\n\t- Dependencies: \n- **Subgoal 6**:\n\t- Title: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- Definition: In a bowl, combine eggs (yolks and optionally whole eggs) with grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses. Add freshly ground black pepper and mix until smooth. Optionally, add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.\n\t- Dependencies: Prepare Ingredients, Toast and Grind Pepper\n- **Subgoal 7**:\n\t- Title: Combine Ingredients\n\t- Definition: Add the cooked pasta to the pan with the guanciale and its rendered fat. Off the heat, quickly add the egg and cheese mixture, stirring vigorously to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if needed.\n\t- Dependencies: Cook Pasta, Prepare Guanciale, Mix Egg and Cheese\n- **Subgoal 8**:\n\t- Title: Serve Carbonara\n\t- Definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, topping it with additional grated cheese, ground black pepper, and reserved crispy guanciale pieces. Serve immediately while hot.\n\t- Dependencies: Combine Ingredients\n"
  },

        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make a foolproof carbonara that is luscious, creamy, and full of flavor, using a few key techniques.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`I'm gonna teach you how to make carbonara that's luscious, creamy, and full of flavor.`; `This is Carbonara 101.`; `If you follow all of my techniques, it'll be foolproof every single time.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing and toasting black peppercorns, grating cheese, preparing eggs, and cutting guanciale. Then, cook pasta and guanciale, and finally mix everything together with the pasta water to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns.`; `I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`; `So let's take our pasta out, right? I drain it, but I don't drain it too well.`; `And then guanciale and all the fat goes in. Don't be shy. And then we mix.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a silky, creamy carbonara with chewy guanciale, a spicy kick from black peppercorns, and a rich flavor from the cheese mixture, making it a satisfying dish.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`The sauce is silky and creamy because I took the time to get everything mixed really well.`; `The guanciale has some chew to it.`; `We get a little bit of spiciness from that black peppercorn and the mixture of both cheeses, sharp and kind of earthy, I think makes this carbonara one of the best versions you'll ever have.`\n"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": [
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Contents:\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "One of the keys to a foolproof carbonara is to gather all of your ingredients. You need everything within arm's reach. So when I cook my pasta, I'm not waiting for anything. I can make it right away."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And as a chef, grating your own cheese is super important. For my carbonara, I choose to use two cheeses. I'm using Parmesan cheese and I'm using Pecorino. And I do buy the good stuff for this. I go to the Italian cheeses. If you can get it, go for the best cheese you can find. I like to use a microplane for this. Now, a microplane is a very fine grater. When this cheese melts, I want it to be nice and fine. I don't wanna get shreds in there. I wanna get this beautiful, fine cheese that's gonna make my sauce super silky in the end. What I like about using two cheeses here is the Parmesan gives me a nice nuttiness and it gives me a really great kind of earthy flavor, whereas the Pecorino is super sharp and it's got a lot of bite to it. So look, I have a lot of cheese here and that's a good thing. That's what I want. So this is for about four servings. Now that my cheese is grated, I can get to my eggs. For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature. So what I'll do is I'll set them on the counter for about a half hour before I make the dish. Because if they're cold, that's gonna slow everything down. I'm gonna put hot pasta and cold eggs and the dish isn't gonna come together and emulsify right. So eggs are the binder for this dish. This is what brings the whole thing together. And I'm going to use three whole eggs and two egg yolks. And what I like to do is crack my egg in half and just run my yolk between the shells until the white all runs out all the way. A lot of times people will just use straight eggs for this and that's okay, but the yolk is a lot of fat and the white is a lot of liquid. So by adding the extra yolk, I'm adding more fat to the dish, more richness to the dish. The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together. And this is a really important step because I want this to be a smooth and creamy sauce around my pasta. We wanna get this into a nice homogenous mixture so that when we actually add the pasta to it, we don't get scrambled eggs. Not a good look for carbonara. All right, so let's just take the cheese, dump it into the eggs and we can just get this together. And you'll see, it's gonna get kind of like a thick, creamy mixture. Get that all in there. I use a whisk just to get this together, but I'm not gonna use a whisk past this point. But you can see, the mixture looks nice and creamy. It's come together. There's no bits of eggs or bits of cheese that aren't mixed in. And that's what I want. This is super important getting your carbonara to the right finished texture. At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns, right? Give it a shake. Get a little bit of your finely ground stuff. Get a little bit of your bigger chunks. So my egg and cheese mixture is ready to go."
      }
    ]
  }
]

      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- ** Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- ** Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n"
      }
    ]
  },
  {
    "role": "user",
    "content": [
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Contents:\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And I'm using dry pasta. It holds the sauce really well. I like to use spaghetti for this. I like the shape. I like the way it holds onto the sauce. I like the bite to it. Pasta's gonna take about 10 minutes, and in that time, I'm going to get my guanciale ready to go. So turn your heat on. I like to use a little olive oil in my pan before I start cooking my guanciale. People will say, but Chef Frank, the guanciale has a lot of fat. I like to put this in the pan to get the process going quicker. My guanciale is gonna brown a little more evenly. I don't really have to wait for that fat to render out. So a little bit of fat in my pan to start is the way that I always go. We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown. You can hear it start to sizzle. I don't want this to be crisp. I want it to have some chew to it in the end. So we're not gonna brown it all the way. We want to keep all the fat. A lot of people say, whoa, that's a lot of fat. We're gonna put that in the pasta? Yes, we're using all the fat. The fat is key to this dish. It's also going to emulsify with the egg yolks and make this sauce super creamy. Don't forget to get in there and stir your pasta occasionally. We don't want it sticking. Well, how do you tell if pasta's done? If you look at it right now, it's still very firm, right? We want it to be nice and al dente, which means to the tooth. We don't want it to be overcooked. We want it to have a little bite to it. My guanciale is ready to go. You can see it's still bubbling away. It's not completely done, but if I leave it in the pan and keep it hot, it's gonna continue to cook. I don't want it to get any more crisp than this. So I think my pasta is ready. The best way to determine if it is, is to take a piece, try not to burn yourself, and actually taste it. And that's good to go."
      }
    ]
  }

Then, cook pasta and guanciale, and finally mix everything together with the pasta water to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns.`; `I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`; `So let's take our pasta out, right? And then we mix.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a silky, creamy carbonara with chewy guanciale, a spicy kick from black peppercorns, and a rich flavor from the cheese mixture, making it a satisfying dish.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`The sauce is silky and creamy because I took the time to get everything mixed really well.`; `The guanciale has some chew to it.`; `We get a little bit of spiciness from that black peppercorn and the mixture of both cheeses, sharp and kind of earthy, I think makes this carbonara one of the best versions you'll ever have.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "Contents:\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "And now it's time for the star of the show, the guanciale. And this is super traditional for carbonara. Now, if you don't have guanciale, if you can't find it where you're at, you can use pancetta. I've seen bacon be used. Traditionally, guanciale is used for carbonara. And that's the jowl or the cheek of the pig that's being cured, salt cured. Sometimes they rub it in spices and sometimes in peppercorn, but it's just cured. It's salty, it's fatty, it's delicious. And that's why they use it. It has that fattiness. When we cook it out, we get a lot of fat that helps make our sauce smooth and creamy. When it comes to guanciale, I like nice big chunks of it. So I like to cut my own. I don't like to buy a precut. So I wanna get nice matchsticks or big mordones or chunks. Don't be shy. I want them to be super visible in my dish. So you see I have kind of like this matchstick or a very thick matchstick. So we're gonna cut those into nice chunks. I don't want any wimpy little chunks. I wanna see this guanciale. It's a beautiful ingredient. It's got some meat on it, but it's not super meaty. Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "A lot of people will mix carbonara in a pan, and I don't like doing it in a pan, right? Pans retain heat. I'm afraid my eggs might overcook and get scrambled. So I like to mix everything in the bowl that I mix the cheese and eggs in. So let's take our pasta out, right? I drain it, but I don't drain it too well. We wanna get a little bit of that pasta water in there. The pasta water has starch. It has a little bit of salt. So this goes right into my eggs. And this is gonna start that process of cooking those eggs. And then guanciale and all the fat goes in. Don't be shy. And then we mix. I have a pair of tongs. And here's the key here. We want to mix, mix, mix, right? We want that egg and that cheese to start to cook. We want that fat to be emulsified into the sauce. But look at that, right? Super creamy. Those eggs start to cook. It smells cheesy. Oh my gosh. Nice big chunks of the guanciale, which this is the important part here. We're emulsifying the sauce around the pasta. All of that fat from the guanciale is getting in there. And we get this beautiful, luscious, creamy sauce. Look at that. It's almost like magic when this sauce comes together."
      }
    ]
  }

    "role": "user",
    "content": [
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Contents:\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns. Now, I like to grind my own, but before I grind them, I like to toast them, and toasting is gonna give us this really nice, nutty, deep black pepper flavor. So put it over kind of mediumlow heat, and we're just gonna put the peppercorns in until I start to smell that they're fragrant. It's just a subtle nuance that makes this dish so much better. Make sure we're moving our peppercorns around so that they toast evenly. So what I'm looking for here is that I can smell my peppercorns getting fragrant. They start to kind of move around in the pan a little. You'll see that they'll jump a little, right? We might hear a little pop, and once I hear that first popping, I take it off. I don't really wanna go any further than that, because then we're gonna get it overcooked. I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients."
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "Now that my peppercorns have cooled, I can crush them. Now, you can use a pepper grinder if you want, but I'm gonna use the old classic technique. I get the pan. I hold it down with my hand here, body weight down. So I'm pushing and rolling. Almost like you're doing a lever, right? I'm pushing down on this side and crushing my peppercorns and rolling. So I can smell, as I crush, that these are super fragrant, super nutty. That toasting brings out those flavors. We get the oils out. And I don't want this to be super fine. I want it to have some texture to it. We're talking about how to take this dish from just kind of a standard dish to just that much better."
      }
    ]
  }
]

The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God. The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

Grate Pecorino Romano cheese. Add pepper. Prepare spaghetti.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.`; `You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.`; `If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.`; `Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.`\n- **Rationale**: The video humorously explains the irrelevance of traditional ingredients since the dish is not authentic carbonara.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.`\n- **Tips**: Avoid using egg yolkles as it ruins the dish. Breaking spaghetti is humorously described as a crime in Italy.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.`; `Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.`\n- **Outcome**: Ingredients are humorously prepared for a non-traditional carbonara dish.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.`\n"

The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

Slice bacon into thick pieces. 2. Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely. 3. Whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. 4. Mix grated cheese into the egg mixture. 5. Add ground black pepper to taste and whisk.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using a mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness without being overwhelming. Mixing two types of cheese adds depth of flavor.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use a cheese grater or box grater for fine cheese texture. Adjust pepper to personal taste.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Prepared mixture of sliced bacon, grated cheese, and whisked eggs with pepper, ready for cooking.\n"

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make traditional Pasta Carbonara correctly, using accessible ingredients like bacon instead of guanciale, and emphasizing the simplicity of the dish without unnecessary additions like cream.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.`; `It's so simple!`; `You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing the bacon by rendering its fat, cooking the pasta, and creating a cheese and egg mixture. The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God. Looks so good.`; `And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.`; `Just get it off the tongs like so. Oh, man.`; `And of course, some of your crispy bacon. Just for an added crunch.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Cook Pasta\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Cook the pasta\n\t- ** Materials**: Spaghetti, pot, water, tongs\n\t- ** Instructions**: 1. Cook the spaghetti in boiling water for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente. 2. Use tongs to transfer the spaghetti to a baking pan.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Cooking the pasta slightly al dente allows it to finish cooking in the sauce, absorbing flavors without becoming mushy.\n\t- ** Tips**: Leave the pasta water in the pot as it will be used later.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Spaghetti is cooked slightly al dente and ready to be combined with other ingredients.\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Render bacon fat\n\t- ** Materials**: Bacon, olive oil, pan, paper towel\n\t- ** Instructions**: 1. Turn the pan on to medium heat. 2. Add a tiny bit of olive oil to the pan. 3. Break bacon into the pan. 4. Slowly render out the fat, turning occasionally. 5. Once crispy, remove some bacon for garnish and drain on a paper towel. 6. Turn off the heat and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Rendering the fat slowly ensures the bacon becomes crispy without burning, and the fat is used to flavor the pasta.\n\t- ** Tips**: Do not add olive oil to the pasta; it's a myth that it helps. Use affordable pasta brands as they work well.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Crispy bacon with rendered fat, some reserved for garnish and some for the pasta.\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Mix Egg and Cheese\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Mix egg-cheese\n\t- ** Materials**: Eggs, grated cheese, boiling water\n\t- ** Instructions**: 1. Take a little bit of boiling water. 2. Add it to the egg mixture. 3. Quickly whisk it in.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Equalizing the temperatures and loosening the egg mixture helps the pasta come together more easily.\n\t- ** Tips**: Add about a quarter cup of boiling water to the egg mixture.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A loosened and temperature-equalized egg and cheese mixture ready to combine with pasta.\n"
      },

Use pasta water to loosen the sauce if it's too thick.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`Because if it doesn't thicken up like you like, literally what you can do is set that pan back on top of that pasta water and like a double boil or bainmarie, it will keep cooking the egg mixture.`; `And if it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water.`\n- **Outcome**: A creamy, velvety sauce coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`You see how creamy this is?`; `And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.`; `Done.         "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`So first up guys, you only need five ingredients.`; `I want to give you what I think is the most authentic recipe.`\n- **Materials**: Guanciale, pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, optional garlic\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`Guanciale. This is the cured cheek of pork.`; `But you can see this is quite lean.`; `Then, most people use parmesan. But actually, the more classic is pecorino romano.`; `Sheep's cheese. It's crumbly, it's salty, freerange organic egg.`; `Pasta, black pepper and then optional, garlic.`\n- **Instructions**: Gather guanciale, pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optional garlic.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`So first up guys, you only need five ingredients.`; `Guanciale. This is the cured cheek of pork.`; `Then, most people use parmesan. But actually, the more classic is pecorino romano.`; `Sheep's cheese. It's crumbly, it's salty, freerange organic egg.`; `Pasta, black pepper and then optional, garlic.`\n- **Rationale**: Using traditional ingredients like guanciale and pecorino romano ensures authenticity in the carbonara recipe.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`I want to give you what I think is the most authentic recipe.`; `Guanciale. This is the cured cheek of pork.`; `Then, most people use parmesan. But actually, the more classic is pecorino romano.`\n- **Tips**: Try to get guanciale with the fat intact for better flavor.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`But you can see this is quite lean. So try and get them to not cut off the fat because you need it.`\n- **Outcome**: All necessary ingredients for spaghetti carbonara are gathered and ready for preparation.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`So first up guys, you only need five ingredients.`\n"

The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare Guanciale\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`So I've got my guanciale.`; `I'm gonna remove the skin and I'm gonna take a nice centimetre slice of the guanciale.`\n- **Materials**: Guanciale, garlic, pan\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`So I've got my guanciale.`; `Give the garlic a crack and then put it in the pan.`\n- **Instructions**: Remove the skin from the guanciale. Slice it into 1 cm pieces. Roughly chop into 0.5 cm chunks. Place in a cold pan. Turn heat to medium-high. Add cracked garlic to the pan.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`I'm gonna remove the skin and I'm gonna take a nice centimetre slice of the guanciale.`; `Roughly chop this to about half centimetre chunks.`; `Now, the pan is cold. Turn it on to a mediumhigh heat.`; `The guanciale goes in to the pan and this pan is getting hot.`; `Give the garlic a crack and then put it in the pan.`\n- **Rationale**: Starting with a cold pan helps to render the fat from the guanciale effectively.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`The reason I want it cold is because I want to render the fat out.`\n- **Tips**: Cracking the garlic helps release its flavor into the fat.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`As this starts to sizzle, the fat will just pull out some of that perfume from the garlic.`\n- **Outcome**: Guanciale is chopped and its fat is rendered in the pan with garlic for flavor.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`The guanciale goes in to the pan and this pan is getting hot.`; `As this starts to sizzle, the fat will just pull out some of that perfume from the garlic.`\n"

The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

The dish is finished by combining the pasta with eggs and pecorino cheese, ensuring the right texture and flavor.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`So first up guys, grab the pasta by two hands. Twist it into the water.`; `The guanciale goes in to the pan and this pan is getting hot.`; `Now, let's get on to the eggs.`; `Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan.`; `That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce.`; `Only then can we think about adding our egg.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a classic spaghetti carbonara with a creamy sauce, rich in flavor from the guanciale and pecorino, and perfectly cooked pasta.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Look at that guys, look at that.         "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Combine Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Combine ingredients properly\n\t- ** Materials**: Cooked pasta, pasta water, rendered guanciale fat, egg and cheese mixture\n\t- ** Instructions**: 1. Remove the garlic from the pan. 2. Turn off the heat. 3. Drag the pasta and some pasta water into the pan with the guanciale fat. 4. Toss the pasta, adding more liquid as needed to create a creamy sauce. 5. Add the egg mixture once the sauce is creamy.\n\t- ** Rationale**: The combination of pasta water and guanciale fat creates a creamy sauce through emulsification, which is essential for the texture of carbonara.\n\t- ** Tips**: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling.         "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare guanciale chunks\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`Now, for the original Carbonara, you need the guanciale, which is the cheek, the pork cheek.`; `Now, you have to cut it in chunks.`\n- **Materials**: Guanciale, olive oil, pan\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`Now, for the original Carbonara, you need the guanciale, which is the cheek, the pork cheek.`; `And the only thing you have to do now to make the sauce is to take good olive oil, put it in the pan.`\n- **Instructions**: Cut the guanciale into big chunks. The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"
