        "type": "text",
        "text": "# New Video\n## Context\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare key ingredients\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks, and then set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry.`\n- **Materials**: Guanciale or pancetta, eggs, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, black pepper\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch.`; `I've got maybe a half pound here that I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks.`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk for a little added richness.`; `And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese.`; `Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano.`; `The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.`\n- **Instructions**: Cut guanciale or pancetta into chunks. Beat three eggs and one yolk. Grate and measure cheese. Mix eggs and cheese. Add black pepper.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks.`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk.`; `And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese.`; `I'm going for a 5050 ratio, into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs.`; `We're then going to beat this whole affair together with a fork until homogenous.`; `The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.`\n- **Rationale**: Using a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano balances sharpness and nuttiness.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano.`; `If you want it a little less sharp and a little more nutty, I'm going for a 5050 ratio.`\n- **Tips**: If guanciale is unavailable, substitute with pancetta.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch.`\n- **Outcome**: Prepared ingredients for Carbonara, including egg and cheese mixture.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry.`\n"
      }

The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"

The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Prepare key ingredients\n\t- ** Materials**: Guanciale or pancetta, eggs, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, black pepper\n\t- ** Instructions**: Cut guanciale or pancetta into chunks. Beat three eggs and one yolk. Grate and measure cheese. Mix eggs and cheese. Add black pepper.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano balances sharpness and nuttiness.\n\t- ** Tips**: If guanciale is unavailable, substitute with pancetta.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Prepared ingredients for Carbonara, including egg and cheese mixture.\n"

Optionally toss to aerate.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Once all the pasta has been added, we're going to toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly covered in all that guanciale fat.`; `So waste no time getting the egg and cheese mixture in there, and then agitate rigorously.`; `If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like, you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a quarter cup.`; `Now we're gonna taste for seasoning.`; `Then you can optionally toss the pasta.`\n- **Rationale**: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, making it smooth and creamy.       "We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara."

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make traditional Pasta Carbonara correctly, using accessible ingredients like bacon instead of guanciale, and emphasizing the simplicity of the dish without unnecessary additions like cream.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.`; `It's so simple!`; `You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing the bacon by rendering its fat, cooking the pasta, and creating a cheese and egg mixture. The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God. Slice bacon into thick pieces. 2. Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely. 3. Whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. 4. Mix grated cheese into the egg mixture. 5. Add ground black pepper to taste and whisk.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding.`; `Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture.`; `Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.`\n- **Rationale**: Using a mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness without being overwhelming. Mixing two types of cheese adds depth of flavor.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks. I like to do a mixture of both.`; `The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks.`; `So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses.`\n- **Tips**: Use a cheese grater or box grater for fine cheese texture. Adjust pepper to personal taste.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater.`; `Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.`\n- **Outcome**: Prepared mixture of sliced bacon, grated cheese, and whisked eggs with pepper, ready for cooking.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`So here's all our beautiful cheese.`; `And so now we have a consistency like this.`\n"

        "text": "# New Video\n## Context\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare key ingredients\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks, and then set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry.`\n- **Materials**: Guanciale or pancetta, eggs, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, black pepper\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch.`; `I've got maybe a half pound here that I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks.`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk for a little added richness.`; `And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese.`; `Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano.`; `The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.`\n- **Instructions**: Cut guanciale or pancetta into chunks. Beat three eggs and one yolk. Grate and measure cheese. Mix eggs and cheese. Add black pepper.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks.`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk.`; `And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese.`; `I'm going for a 5050 ratio, into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs.`; `We're then going to beat this whole affair together with a fork until homogenous.`; `The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.`\n- **Rationale**: Using a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano balances sharpness and nuttiness.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano.`; `If you want it a little less sharp and a little more nutty, I'm going for a 5050 ratio.`\n- **Tips**: If guanciale is unavailable, substitute with pancetta.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch.`\n- **Outcome**: Prepared ingredients for Carbonara, including egg and cheese mixture.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry.`\n"

Add ground black pepper to taste and whisk.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using a mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness without being overwhelming. Mixing two types of cheese adds depth of flavor.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use a cheese grater or box grater for fine cheese texture. Adjust pepper to personal taste.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Prepared mixture of sliced bacon, grated cheese, and whisked eggs with pepper, ready for cooking.\n"

The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God.         "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"
      },

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Combine Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Combine ingredients effectively\n\t- ** Materials**: Pasta, guanciale fat, egg and cheese mixture, pasta water (optional)\n\t- ** Instructions**: Toss pasta in guanciale fat. Quickly add egg and cheese mixture. Agitate to emulsify. Add pasta water if needed. Taste and adjust seasoning. Optionally toss to aerate.\n\t- ** Rationale**: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, making it smooth and creamy. Agitating helps emulsify the sauce and prevents curdling.\n\t- ** Tips**: Work quickly to prevent the eggs from curdling. Add pasta water if the sauce isn't smooth enough.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A creamy, emulsified Carbonara sauce coating the pasta evenly.\n"

Grab the pasta by two hands. 2. Twist it into the water. 3. Add a tiny amount of salt to the water.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`grab the pasta by two hands`; `Twist it into the water`; `Put a tiny amount of salt in this water`\n- **Rationale**: Twisting the pasta prevents it from sticking together, and adding only a tiny amount of salt is important because the cheese and guanciale are already salty.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`By twisting it, it won't stick together.`; `Put a tiny amount of salt in this water because the cheese and the guanciale is salty.`\n- **Tips**: \n- **Outcome**: Pasta is submerged in salted boiling water, ready to cook without sticking together.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`Twist it into the water.       "The water is salato come in mare, or as salty as the sea."
    ],

      "Put a tiny amount of salt in this water"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"

Slice it into 1 cm pieces. Roughly chop into 0.5 cm chunks. Place in a cold pan. Turn heat to medium-high. Add cracked garlic to the pan.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`I'm gonna remove the skin and I'm gonna take a nice centimetre slice of the guanciale.`; `Roughly chop this to about half centimetre chunks.`; `Now, the pan is cold.         "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Combine ingredients properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan.`; `Only then can we think about adding our egg.`\n- **Materials**: Cooked pasta, pasta water, rendered guanciale fat, egg and cheese mixture\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`We've got dark guanciale.`; `Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan.`; `Only then can we think about adding our egg.`\n- **Instructions**: 1. Remove the garlic from the pan. 2. Turn off the heat. 3. Drag the pasta and some pasta water into the pan with the guanciale fat. 4. Toss the pasta, adding more liquid as needed to create a creamy sauce. 5. Add the egg mixture once the sauce is creamy.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Now, I'm gonna remove that garlic.`; `Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan.`; `As we toss, we add some more liquid.`; `Only then can we think about adding our egg.`\n- **Rationale**: The combination of pasta water and guanciale fat creates a creamy sauce through emulsification, which is essential for the texture of carbonara.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce.`; `You get the cream through the emulsification of the cooking water and the fat and technique and timing.`\n- **Tips**: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling.       },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Combine ingredients effectively\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`Once all the pasta has been added, we're going to toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly covered in all that guanciale fat.`; `So waste no time getting the egg and cheese mixture in there, and then agitate rigorously.`\n- **Materials**: Pasta, guanciale fat, egg and cheese mixture, pasta water (optional)\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`Once all the pasta has been added, we're going to toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly covered in all that guanciale fat.`; `So waste no time getting the egg and cheese mixture in there, and then agitate rigorously.`; `If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like, you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a quarter cup.`\n- **Instructions**: Toss pasta in guanciale fat. Quickly add egg and cheese mixture. Agitate to emulsify. Add pasta water if needed. Taste and adjust seasoning. Optionally toss to aerate.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Once all the pasta has been added, we're going to toss it around in the pan, ensuring that it is evenly covered in all that guanciale fat.`; `So waste no time getting the egg and cheese mixture in there, and then agitate rigorously.`; `If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like, you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a quarter cup.`; `Now we're gonna taste for seasoning.`; `Then you can optionally toss the pasta.`\n- **Rationale**: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, making it smooth and creamy. Agitating helps emulsify the sauce and prevents curdling.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `This is going to help emulsify the sauce and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling.`\n- **Tips**: Work quickly to prevent the eggs from curdling. Add pasta water if the sauce isn't smooth enough.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`And you wanna work quickly here, because the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta.`; `If you find that it's not as smooth as you'd like, you can add a little bit of pasta water, like a quarter cup.`\n- **Outcome**: A creamy, emulsified Carbonara sauce coating the pasta evenly.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`This is going to help emulsify the sauce and keep it creamy and prevent it from curdling.`; `But ideally, it should look just like this.`\n"

The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"

Add black pepper.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano balances sharpness and nuttiness.\n\t- ** Tips**: If guanciale is unavailable, substitute with pancetta.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Prepared ingredients for Carbonara, including egg and cheese mixture.\n"

        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make two versions of Pasta Carbonara: a traditional Italian version and a modern, less traditional version.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`today we're going to take a crack at two different versions of Carbonara, a realdeal, oldschool Italian version, and a more modern, less traditional version`; `Let's get down to basics.Carbonara`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The video outlines the process of making traditional Carbonara by preparing guanciale, creating an egg and cheese mixture, cooking the pasta, and combining these elements to form a creamy sauce. The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"

Stir to coat the pasta with the sauce.\n\t- ** Rationale**: The guanciale and pasta should not be too hot to prevent the eggs from scrambling, ensuring a creamy sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Turn off the heat before adding the egg mixture to avoid scrambling.\n\t- ** Outcome**: The pasta is coated with a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs, resulting in authentic Carbonara.\n"
      },

The modern version follows a similar process but uses bacon and adds garlic for a lighter sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`before we can make Carbonara, we've got to make Carbonara, which, by definition, is made with guanciale`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk`; `we are introducing the guanciale to a cold pan`; `Once the pasta's done, we're dumping it directly into the saute pan with the guanciale`; `the only thing that's going to cook our egg slurry and make it smooth and creamy is the residual heat from the pasta`; `we're gonna start these guys off in a cold pan`; `strain off all but about two tablespoons worth of bacon fat`; `add the most egregious ingredient of all, garlic`; `we're adding the pasta directly to the pan, but this time we're gonna add about a third of a cup of starchy pasta water`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is two versions of Pasta Carbonara: the traditional version with a rich, creamy sauce and the modern version with a lighter sauce that stays creamier longer.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Carbonara.In its purest, most authentic and traditional form.`; `the sauce is much lighter, because it has a lot less fat.It also stays creamier longer`\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Combine Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Combine ingredients effectively\n\t- ** Materials**: Pasta, guanciale fat, egg and cheese mixture, pasta water (optional)\n\t- ** Instructions**: Toss pasta in guanciale fat. Quickly add egg and cheese mixture. Agitate to emulsify. Add pasta water if needed. Taste and adjust seasoning. Optionally toss to aerate.\n\t- ** Rationale**: The residual heat from the pasta cooks the egg mixture, making it smooth and creamy. Agitating helps emulsify the sauce and prevents curdling.\n\t- ** Tips**: Work quickly to prevent the eggs from curdling. Add pasta water if the sauce isn't smooth enough.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A creamy, emulsified Carbonara sauce coating the pasta evenly.\n"

        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make a foolproof carbonara that is luscious, creamy, and full of flavor, using a few key techniques.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`I'm gonna teach you how to make carbonara that's luscious, creamy, and full of flavor.`; `This is Carbonara 101.`; `If you follow all of my techniques, it'll be foolproof every single time.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing and toasting black peppercorns, grating cheese, preparing eggs, and cutting guanciale. Then, cook pasta and guanciale, and finally mix everything together with the pasta water to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns.`; `I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`; `So let's take our pasta out, right? I drain it, but I don't drain it too well.`; `And then guanciale and all the fat goes in. Don't be shy. And then we mix.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a silky, creamy carbonara with chewy guanciale, a spicy kick from black peppercorns, and a rich flavor from the cheese mixture, making it a satisfying dish.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`The sauce is silky and creamy because I took the time to get everything mixed really well.`; `The guanciale has some chew to it.`; `We get a little bit of spiciness from that black peppercorn and the mixture of both cheeses, sharp and kind of earthy, I think makes this carbonara one of the best versions you'll ever have.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`One of the keys to a foolproof carbonara is to gather all of your ingredients.`; `You need everything within arm's reach.`; `So when I cook my pasta, I'm not waiting for anything.`\n- **Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`I'm using Parmesan cheese and I'm using Pecorino.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Grating your own cheese is super important.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'm going to use three whole eggs and two egg yolks.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Let's just take the cheese, dump it into the eggs and we can just get this together.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`When this cheese melts, I want it to be nice and fine.`; `If they're cold, that's gonna slow everything down.`; `The yolk is a lot of fat and the white is a lot of liquid.`; `By adding the extra yolk, I'm adding more fat to the dish, more richness to the dish.`; `We wanna get this into a nice homogenous mixture so that when we actually add the pasta to it, we don't get scrambled eggs.`\n- **Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`If you can get it, go for the best cheese you can find.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'll set them on the counter for about a half hour before I make the dish.`\n- **Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`The mixture looks nice and creamy.`; `It's come together.`; `There's no bits of eggs or bits of cheese that aren't mixed in.`; `This is super important getting your carbonara to the right finished texture.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare key ingredients\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks, and then set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry.`\n- **Materials**: Guanciale or pancetta, eggs, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, black pepper\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch.`; `I've got maybe a half pound here that I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks.`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk for a little added richness.`; `And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese.`; `Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano.`; `The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.`\n- **Instructions**: Cut guanciale or pancetta into chunks. Beat three eggs and one yolk. Grate and measure cheese. Mix eggs and cheese. Add black pepper.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`I'm gonna cut into relatively sizable chunks.`; `Into a medium bowl or measuring cup goes three large eggs and one egg yolk.`; `And then it's time to finely grate and measure out four ounces of cheese.`; `I'm going for a 5050 ratio, into which I'm going to dump our beaten eggs.`; `We're then going to beat this whole affair together with a fork until homogenous.`; `The only other thing you're gonna want to add is a whole lot of freshly ground black pepper.`\n- **Rationale**: Using a mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano balances sharpness and nuttiness.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`Truly traditional Carbonara uses 100 Pecorino Romano cheese, but is commonly balanced out with ParmigianoReggiano.`; `If you want it a little less sharp and a little more nutty, I'm going for a 5050 ratio.`\n- **Tips**: If guanciale is unavailable, substitute with pancetta.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`It is very delicious, but a little hard to find, so if you can't find it, you can sub with pancetta if you're in a pinch.`\n- **Outcome**: Prepared ingredients for Carbonara, including egg and cheese mixture.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`set aside to make one of the essential elements of any Carbonara dish, the egg slurry.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "# Previous Video\n## Context\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make a foolproof carbonara that is luscious, creamy, and full of flavor, using a few key techniques.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`I'm gonna teach you how to make carbonara that's luscious, creamy, and full of flavor.`; `This is Carbonara 101.`; `If you follow all of my techniques, it'll be foolproof every single time.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing and toasting black peppercorns, grating cheese, preparing eggs, and cutting guanciale. Then, cook pasta and guanciale, and finally mix everything together with the pasta water to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns.`; `I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`; `So let's take our pasta out, right? I drain it, but I don't drain it too well.`; `And then guanciale and all the fat goes in. Don't be shy. And then we mix.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a silky, creamy carbonara with chewy guanciale, a spicy kick from black peppercorns, and a rich flavor from the cheese mixture, making it a satisfying dish.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`The sauce is silky and creamy because I took the time to get everything mixed really well.`; `The guanciale has some chew to it.`; `We get a little bit of spiciness from that black peppercorn and the mixture of both cheeses, sharp and kind of earthy, I think makes this carbonara one of the best versions you'll ever have.`\n"
      },

        "type": "text",

Add salt to the boiling water until it is sea salty.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Salting the water properly is crucial for seasoning the pasta as it cooks.\n\t- ** Tips**: Prepare all ingredients within arm's reach for efficient cooking.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Boiling water that is salted to taste like the sea, ready for cooking pasta.\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- ** Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- ** Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n"
      },

        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Cook pasta properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`Pasta's gonna take about 10 minutes, and in that time, I'm going to get my guanciale ready to go.`; `So I think my pasta is ready.`; `The best way to determine if it is, is to take a piece, try not to burn yourself, and actually taste it.`\n- **Materials**: Dry spaghetti pasta, olive oil, guanciale\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`And I'm using dry pasta.`; `I like to use spaghetti for this.`; `I like to use a little olive oil in my pan before I start cooking my guanciale.`; `My guanciale is gonna brown a little more evenly.`\n- **Instructions**: 1. Boil dry spaghetti pasta for about 10 minutes. 2. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking. 3. Taste to check if pasta is al dente. 4. Heat pan with olive oil. 5. Cook guanciale until light golden brown, ensuring it retains some chew.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Pasta's gonna take about 10 minutes.`; `Don't forget to get in there and stir your pasta occasionally.`; `The best way to determine if it is, is to take a piece, try not to burn yourself, and actually taste it.`; `Turn your heat on.`; `I like to use a little olive oil in my pan before I start cooking my guanciale.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`\n- **Rationale**: Using dry pasta helps hold the sauce well. Olive oil helps guanciale brown evenly and quickly. Retaining guanciale fat is crucial for emulsifying with egg yolks to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`And I'm using dry pasta. It holds the sauce really well.`; `I like to use a little olive oil in my pan before I start cooking my guanciale.`; `The fat is key to this dish. It's also going to emulsify with the egg yolks and make this sauce super creamy.`\n- **Tips**: Taste pasta to ensure it's al dente. Avoid overcooking guanciale to keep it chewy.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`The best way to determine if it is, is to take a piece, try not to burn yourself, and actually taste it.`; `I don't want this to be crisp. I want it to have some chew to it in the end.`\n- **Outcome**: Cooked al dente pasta and browned guanciale with retained fat for sauce.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`We want it to be nice and al dente, which means to the tooth.`; `My guanciale is ready to go.`; `It's not completely done, but if I leave it in the pan and keep it hot, it's gonna continue to cook.`\n"

The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`One of the keys to a foolproof carbonara is to gather all of your ingredients.`; `You need everything within arm's reach.`; `So when I cook my pasta, I'm not waiting for anything.`\n- **Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`I'm using Parmesan cheese and I'm using Pecorino.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Grating your own cheese is super important.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'm going to use three whole eggs and two egg yolks.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Let's just take the cheese, dump it into the eggs and we can just get this together.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`When this cheese melts, I want it to be nice and fine.`; `If they're cold, that's gonna slow everything down.`; `The yolk is a lot of fat and the white is a lot of liquid.`; `By adding the extra yolk, I'm adding more fat to the dish, more richness to the dish.`; `We wanna get this into a nice homogenous mixture so that when we actually add the pasta to it, we don't get scrambled eggs.`\n- **Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`If you can get it, go for the best cheese you can find.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'll set them on the counter for about a half hour before I make the dish.`\n- **Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`The mixture looks nice and creamy.`; `It's come together.`; `There's no bits of eggs or bits of cheese that aren't mixed in.`; `This is super important getting your carbonara to the right finished texture.`\n"

The process is filled with comedic commentary and intentional deviations from traditional Carbonara methods.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.`; `Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.`; `Grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.`; `Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.`; `Now our bacon is cooked.`; `Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.`; `Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a dish that humorously resembles Pasta Carbonara but is intentionally not authentic, as it uses bacon instead of guanciale and includes comedic elements like adding peas.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`And here we don't have carbonara.`; `I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.`\n"

Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n"

Avoid overcooking guanciale to keep it chewy.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`The best way to determine if it is, is to take a piece, try not to burn yourself, and actually taste it.`; `I don't want this to be crisp. I want it to have some chew to it in the end.`\n- **Outcome**: Cooked al dente pasta and browned guanciale with retained fat for sauce.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`We want it to be nice and al dente, which means to the tooth.`; `My guanciale is ready to go.`; `It's not completely done, but if I leave it in the pan and keep it hot, it's gonna continue to cook.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- ** Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- ** Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "# Previous Video\n## Context\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make traditional Pasta Carbonara correctly, using accessible ingredients like bacon instead of guanciale, and emphasizing the simplicity of the dish without unnecessary additions like cream.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.`; `It's so simple!`; `You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing the bacon by rendering its fat, cooking the pasta, and creating a cheese and egg mixture. The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God. Looks so good.`; `And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.`; `Just get it off the tongs like so. Oh, man.`; `And of course, some of your crispy bacon. Just for an added crunch.`\n"
      },

        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients mixture\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.`; `So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine.`; `I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture.`; `I'm gonna put quite a bit of Gilbert's insides into this egg mixture.`\n- **Materials**: Bacon, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, eggs, black pepper, cheese grater or box grater.\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.`; `I love Parmigiano Reggiano.`; `I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Gilbert is just fresh ground black pepper.`\n- **Instructions**: 1. Slice bacon into thick pieces. 2. Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely. 3. Whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. 4. Mix grated cheese into the egg mixture. 5. Add ground black pepper to taste and whisk.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding.`; `Go ahead and whisk that all up, and then we'll start whisking our cheese into our egg mixture.`; `Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.`\n- **Rationale**: Using a mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness without being overwhelming. Mixing two types of cheese adds depth of flavor.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks. I like to do a mixture of both.`; `The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks.`; `So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses.`\n- **Tips**: Use a cheese grater or box grater for fine cheese texture. Adjust pepper to personal taste.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater.`; `Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.`\n- **Outcome**: Prepared mixture of sliced bacon, grated cheese, and whisked eggs with pepper, ready for cooking.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`So here's all our beautiful cheese.`; `And so now we have a consistency like this.`\n"

        "text": "# New Video\n## Context\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make a foolproof carbonara that is luscious, creamy, and full of flavor, using a few key techniques.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`I'm gonna teach you how to make carbonara that's luscious, creamy, and full of flavor.`; `This is Carbonara 101.`; `If you follow all of my techniques, it'll be foolproof every single time.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing and toasting black peppercorns, grating cheese, preparing eggs, and cutting guanciale. Then, cook pasta and guanciale, and finally mix everything together with the pasta water to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns.`; `I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`; `So let's take our pasta out, right? I drain it, but I don't drain it too well.`; `And then guanciale and all the fat goes in. Don't be shy. And then we mix.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a silky, creamy carbonara with chewy guanciale, a spicy kick from black peppercorns, and a rich flavor from the cheese mixture, making it a satisfying dish.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`The sauce is silky and creamy because I took the time to get everything mixed really well.`; `The guanciale has some chew to it.`; `We get a little bit of spiciness from that black peppercorn and the mixture of both cheeses, sharp and kind of earthy, I think makes this carbonara one of the best versions you'll ever have.`\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`One of the keys to a foolproof carbonara is to gather all of your ingredients.`; `You need everything within arm's reach.`; `So when I cook my pasta, I'm not waiting for anything.`\n- **Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`I'm using Parmesan cheese and I'm using Pecorino.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Grating your own cheese is super important.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'm going to use three whole eggs and two egg yolks.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Let's just take the cheese, dump it into the eggs and we can just get this together.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`When this cheese melts, I want it to be nice and fine.`; `If they're cold, that's gonna slow everything down.`; `The yolk is a lot of fat and the white is a lot of liquid.`; `By adding the extra yolk, I'm adding more fat to the dish, more richness to the dish.`; `We wanna get this into a nice homogenous mixture so that when we actually add the pasta to it, we don't get scrambled eggs.`\n- **Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`If you can get it, go for the best cheese you can find.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'll set them on the counter for about a half hour before I make the dish.`\n- **Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`The mixture looks nice and creamy.`; `It's come together.`; `There's no bits of eggs or bits of cheese that aren't mixed in.`; `This is super important getting your carbonara to the right finished texture.`\n"
      }
    ]
  }

The cooked pasta is then combined with the bacon, its fat, and the cheese-egg mixture off the heat to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs. The dish is finished with additional cheese and crispy bacon as garnish.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.`; `So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.`; `Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit.`; `So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.`; `Now we're going to add in that beautiful egg and cheese mixture.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a creamy, velvety Pasta Carbonara with a rich flavor from the cheese and bacon, topped with crispy bacon for added texture.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Oh, my God.         "type": "text",

Bring four quarts of water to a boil. 2. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the boiling water.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`pasta water is coming up to a boil`; `we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water`\n- **Rationale**: Less salt is added to the pasta water because carbonara contains many salty elements.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.`\n- **Tips**: \n- **Outcome**: Pasta water is boiling and seasoned with salt, ready for cooking pasta.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`pasta water is coming up to a boil`; `we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Boil salted water\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`My water is boiling.`; `I'm going to add some salt to my water.`\n- **Materials**: Water, salt\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`My water is boiling.`; `I'm going to add some salt to my water.`\n- **Instructions**: 1. Ensure water is boiling. 2. Add salt to the boiling water until it is sea salty.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`My water is boiling.`; `I'm going to add some salt to my water.`; `I want my water to be basically sea salty.`\n- **Rationale**: Salting the water properly is crucial for seasoning the pasta as it cooks.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`I want my water to be basically sea salty.`\n- **Tips**: Prepare all ingredients within arm's reach for efficient cooking.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`You'll notice in front of me, I have all the ingredients I need within arm's reach.`; `This is one of those things as a chef that you have to set yourself up for. It's proper mise en place.`\n- **Outcome**: Boiling water that is salted to taste like the sea, ready for cooking pasta.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`I want my water to be basically sea salty.`\n"

        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Parent Subgoal**: Prepare Ingredients\n\t- ** Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients mixture\n\t- ** Materials**: Bacon, Pecorino Romano cheese, Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, eggs, black pepper, cheese grater or box grater.\n\t- ** Instructions**: 1. Slice bacon into thick pieces. 2. Grate Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses finely. 3. Whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. 4. Mix grated cheese into the egg mixture. 5. Add ground black pepper to taste and whisk.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using a mixture of whole eggs and yolks balances richness without being overwhelming. Mixing two types of cheese adds depth of flavor.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use a cheese grater or box grater for fine cheese texture. Adjust pepper to personal taste.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Prepared mixture of sliced bacon, grated cheese, and whisked eggs with pepper, ready for cooking.\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },

Cook the spaghetti in boiling water for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente. 2. Use tongs to transfer the spaghetti to a baking pan.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`So we'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente.`; `We're just going to use our tongs here. Drop that in there.`\n- **Rationale**: Cooking the pasta slightly al dente allows it to finish cooking in the sauce, absorbing flavors without becoming mushy.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`Trust me, this spaghetti is generating a ridiculous amount of heat.`\n- **Tips**: Leave the pasta water in the pot as it will be used later.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`Remember, still no heat on this pan. I'm going to explain all this soon, but you want to leave this water in this pot.`\n- **Outcome**: Spaghetti is cooked slightly al dente and ready to be combined with other ingredients.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`It's been 10 minutes. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- ** Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n"

        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Combine ingredients carefully\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`The whole trick here, and what you really need to keep in mind is that we do not want to scramble these eggs.`; `The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`\n- **Materials**: Cooked pasta, bacon fat, cheese and egg mixture, pasta water, pan\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta.`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`; `I'm also using these La Crusade pans, which I'll link in the description, and they hold a lot of heat.`\n- **Instructions**: 1. Combine the cooked pasta with the bacon fat and cheese-egg mixture off the heat. 2. Gently mix to avoid breaking the pasta and scrambling the eggs. 3. If needed, use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`The whole trick here, and what you really need to keep in mind is that we do not want to scramble these eggs.`; `And gentle with the pasta. You don't want to break it.`; `And the pasta water, the bacon fat, the cheese and egg mixture is now emulsifying all over this pasta.`; `And if it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water.`\n- **Rationale**: The heat from the pasta gently cooks the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. Using pasta water helps adjust the sauce consistency.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`The eggs are going to cook from the heat of this pasta and very gently and beautifully in a velvety, fluffy, creamy way, coat it all up, right?`; `And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.`\n- **Tips**: If the sauce doesn't thicken as desired, place the pan over the pasta water to gently heat it like a bain-marie. Use pasta water to loosen the sauce if it's too thick.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`Because if it doesn't thicken up like you like, literally what you can do is set that pan back on top of that pasta water and like a double boil or bainmarie, it will keep cooking the egg mixture.`; `And if it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water.`\n- **Outcome**: A creamy, velvety sauce coats the pasta without scrambling the eggs.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`You see how creamy this is?`; `And help establish that creamy sauce that has no cream.`; `Done. No scramble, nothing.`\n"
      }

Cook guanciale until light golden brown, ensuring it retains some chew.\n\t- ** Rationale**: Using dry pasta helps hold the sauce well. Olive oil helps guanciale brown evenly and quickly. Retaining guanciale fat is crucial for emulsifying with egg yolks to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- ** Tips**: Taste pasta to ensure it's al dente. Avoid overcooking guanciale to keep it chewy.\n\t- ** Outcome**: Cooked al dente pasta and browned guanciale with retained fat for sauce.\n"

      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "\n## Contents\n"
      },
      {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Subgoal**: Prepare ingredients properly\n\t- **Subgoal Quotes**:`One of the keys to a foolproof carbonara is to gather all of your ingredients.`; `You need everything within arm's reach.`; `So when I cook my pasta, I'm not waiting for anything.`\n- **Materials**: Parmesan cheese, Pecorino cheese, eggs, microplane, toasted black peppercorns\n\t- **Materials Quotes**:`I'm using Parmesan cheese and I'm using Pecorino.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Instructions**: Grate Parmesan and Pecorino cheese using a microplane. Set eggs to room temperature. Crack three whole eggs and two yolks, separating whites. Mix eggs and cheese to a homogenous mixture. Add toasted black peppercorns.\n\t- **Instructions Quotes**:`Grating your own cheese is super important.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'm going to use three whole eggs and two egg yolks.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Let's just take the cheese, dump it into the eggs and we can just get this together.`; `At this point, I wanna add a little bit of my toasted black peppercorns.`\n- **Rationale**: Grating cheese finely ensures it melts smoothly for a silky sauce. Room temperature eggs help emulsify the sauce properly. Extra yolks add richness. Mixing eggs and cheese prevents scrambled eggs in the sauce.\n\t- **Rationale Quotes**:`When this cheese melts, I want it to be nice and fine.`; `If they're cold, that's gonna slow everything down.`; `The yolk is a lot of fat and the white is a lot of liquid.`; `By adding the extra yolk, I'm adding more fat to the dish, more richness to the dish.`; `We wanna get this into a nice homogenous mixture so that when we actually add the pasta to it, we don't get scrambled eggs.`\n- **Tips**: Use the best quality cheese you can find for better flavor. Use a microplane for fine grating. Let eggs sit out for half an hour to reach room temperature.\n\t- **Tips Quotes**:`If you can get it, go for the best cheese you can find.`; `I like to use a microplane for this.`; `For carbonara, I like my eggs to be room temperature.`; `I'll set them on the counter for about a half hour before I make the dish.`\n- **Outcome**: A smooth and creamy egg and cheese mixture ready for making carbonara.\n\t- **Outcome Quotes**:`The mixture looks nice and creamy.`; `It's come together.`; `There's no bits of eggs or bits of cheese that aren't mixed in.`; `This is super important getting your carbonara to the right finished texture.`\n"

The dish is finished by combining the pasta with eggs and pecorino cheese, ensuring the right texture and flavor.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`So first up guys, grab the pasta by two hands. Twist it into the water.`; `The guanciale goes in to the pan and this pan is getting hot.`; `Now, let's get on to the eggs.`; `Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan.`; `That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce.`; `Only then can we think about adding our egg.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a classic spaghetti carbonara with a creamy sauce, rich in flavor from the guanciale and pecorino, and perfectly cooked pasta.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`Look at that guys, look at that.       {
        "type": "text",
        "text": "- **Overall Goal**: The main purpose of the video is to teach viewers how to make a foolproof carbonara that is luscious, creamy, and full of flavor, using a few key techniques.\n\t- **Overall Goal Quotes**:`I'm gonna teach you how to make carbonara that's luscious, creamy, and full of flavor.`; `This is Carbonara 101.`; `If you follow all of my techniques, it'll be foolproof every single time.`\n- **Overall Procedure**: The process involves preparing and toasting black peppercorns, grating cheese, preparing eggs, and cutting guanciale. Then, cook pasta and guanciale, and finally mix everything together with the pasta water to create a creamy sauce.\n\t- **Overall Procedure Quotes**:`One of the most important ingredients in carbonara is black peppercorns.`; `I'm gonna let these cool on this tray, and in the meantime, I'm gonna start prepping my other ingredients.`; `The next thing I'm gonna do is I'm gonna mix my eggs and cheese together.`; `Now that I have my guanciale cut, my eggs, cheese, and pepper mixture, we are ready to make our carbonara.`; `We're gonna cook this until it is light golden brown.`; `So let's take our pasta out, right? I drain it, but I don't drain it too well.`; `And then guanciale and all the fat goes in. Don't be shy. And then we mix.`\n- **Overall Outcome**: The final outcome is a silky, creamy carbonara with chewy guanciale, a spicy kick from black peppercorns, and a rich flavor from the cheese mixture, making it a satisfying dish.\n\t- **Overall Outcome Quotes**:`The sauce is silky and creamy because I took the time to get everything mixed really well.`; `The guanciale has some chew to it.`; `We get a little bit of spiciness from that black peppercorn and the mixture of both cheeses, sharp and kind of earthy, I think makes this carbonara one of the best versions you'll ever have.`\n"
